title: Regarding Voice Chat & Leauge
body: A couple of my ranked games I've used skype to communicate with random people who I got on my team in ranked. Not a single one of those games did anyone get reported. Why did no one get reported? Because no one was toxic. Why was no one toxic? Because people are keyboard warriors and can't say half the things they want to say in voice. Even in the games where I had a 0/8 (or something like that) morgana who thought she was front line nobody flamed the guy. Yes, I understand that people can and will still be toxic in voice chat if it's ever implemented into league. But the truth is it won't be as bad as Riot makes it out to be. We can increase communication, synergy, and all the good stuff. Also mic muting would pretty much solve all those spooky toxic kids riot is afraid of.

replies.body:
Ironically, I just answered a question about voice chat on Ask.fm, which is here:

_QUESTION: Are you trying to make the game full PG? (Like even below PG-13) Couse it looks like you are trying to completely remove toxicity when there will always be people that act ughh... silly.Couse for example, voice chat would help immensly but your toxicity "excuse" ruins that idea..._

League is a hardcore game, and it's played by many adults so no, we're not trying to make it a PG-13 game. In fact, we're not against offensive language per se. For example, saying "Fuck I missed that skillshot" or "Fuck, that was a bad engage, sorry" is completely fine and is not punished. You're only punished when you start focusing your language against someone else, for example, "Fuck you asshole, wtf was that play. Uninstll plz." Of course, hate speech, death threats and more severe language is not OK in any context, and that stuff will be punished with pretty much zero tolerance.

With regards to voice chat, we're not opposed to voice chat. A lot of research suggests that voice chat between friends is an awesome experience, but voice chat with strangers is more hit and miss. These are known problems with voice chat and these issues exist in every game. If we do voice chat, we'd like to try some new features to tackle these problems but right now, all our development teams are focused on other priorities.

To the OP though, there's a huge difference between 3rd party voice chat and integrated voice chat. Players that already have a voice chat solution installed, **and are willing to add a stranger to their personal voice chat friends list and voice chat in a game** are a very different, self-selected population compared to the general playerbase. In many cases, you could say these players are more likely to **want** to voice chat with others and very few people would do this purposely to yell at someone or be toxic to someone. If we had integrated voice chat, it would be available for **everyone** in the game, which has very different player behaviors.

FWIWâ€”I'm one of the people who would disable voice chat if it became a feature. This might sound kind of antisocial, but I don't want to listen to League players talking at me. It's a bit too immersive, too demanding in terms of attention and engagement. I'm happy with the other people on my team being (hopefully friendly) text-based creatures. I view voice chat as more something I do with friends when we want to be super tryhard, or just have a pleasant chat while we play League to catch up.

And that's without factoring in the "screaming 12-year-olds" and related voice chat nightmares. (To ward off the inevitable "just mute them" responses: first, muting is a last-ditch response to toxicity, not something that makes it irrelevant, and second, once voice chat becomes a feature, it becomes expected that people will use it, meaning that using the "mute" option bears the cost of eliminating a significant share of communication bandwidth. Muting is a last-ditch option to make a sucky situation somewhat less sucky.)

> why not make voice chat a choice though, so people comfortable could use it?

Because it then becomes the expectation as it is a tool available.
Why no use smart ping? It's available!
Why no keep track of timers? It's in game now!
Why didn't you practice that build on <Insert perceived tier of lower play than what you are doing now. EG, practicing in Team Builder/Normal instead of Ranked. Practicing in Bots instead of Teambuilder/Normal>? It's available.

Those are all things that can be seen happening to players now; not universally mind you, but consistently enough that other threads have discussed those problems before.

By making it in client it becomes an implied mandatory thing to utilize.


When we get past expectations of using of tools: Riot tries to make the game as Toaster Friendly as possible, both on processing power and on Bandwidth. Voice Communication is costly on both aspects and would potentially remove customers.

After all of that, then we have the potential abuses to worry about. Harassment of Grill Gamers, Toxicity/verbal abuse that cannot be readily tracked without some severe privacy intrusions, Squeakers ala the COD community, people who don't understand mic etiquette and have their vacuum cleaner going on right next to their mic and destroying your ears.

Lots of little problems with the idea of pre-built in Voice ,hell WoW has had it built in for a while and they haven't gotten it right yet as people STILL use things like Teamspeak/Vent/Skype for raids.

My friends and I use teamspeak. We invited someone on to play with use, and I was able to ban him when he started harrassing individuals. To me that's the same as muting someone.

I also feel that with nearly every game having integrated voice chat, league is a bit behind the times.

Can you make it so everyone in the game is muted as soon as the game starts?  That way as the player I am assuming the responsibility and accepting the consequences of unmuting my teammates.
I know allchat has to be enabled by the user, but teammates can be quite problematic as well, and very detrimental to my lategame power fantasy of thematic toxicity, I require a safe space if you will.

>Also mic muting would pretty much solve all those spooky toxic kids riot is afraid of.

No, it wouldn't.
>We consider the "Mute" feature to be a last resort. When a player has to use the "Mute" feature, the damage has already been done. Your experience is already worse, you are already less likely to play another game, and you already don't enjoy League as much as before. The "Mute" feature is a last resort to prevent any further harassment or abuse. Just because a feature like this exists doesn't mean it's OK for players to spew hate speech or be racist or verbally abusive. The vast majority of players in League hate these types of behaviors, and we should respect these players and not tell toxic players it's OK to be dicks just because a "Mute" feature exists.

Lyte said this a few months ago. "Just mute them" is never a solution. Whether it's voice or text, it doesn't matter.

Reporting toxic people on voice chat is a huge hurdle as well. Riot would have to listen to an entire recording instead of simply scanning a chat log unless you somehow provided timestamps with your report. Who the hell is going to remember exactly when the Thresh told you to kill yourself? No one I know of provides timestamps with reports right now.

Also "a couple of my ranked games" is a laughably small sample size.

All this is in addition to the great point Lyte himself brought up, where the type of person who actively seeks out communication with teammates through a third party program are generally the type of people who purposefully will not be toxic; and do not represent the vast majority of League players since I don't know of anyone in a single game of mine that has announced "Hey guys, here's my skype name. Hit me up." in champ select. And I've been around since season 3.

"Just mute them" is a solution for the **individual**. A war on toxicity is like the War on Drugs. It exists. It's never going away. Riot's community team will never be able to stop more than several million people's toxicity.

When I say "it exists" I mean it exists in the entire gaming community as a whole. Every single multiplayer game has trolls, manchildren, flamers, and baiters, and generally just people that make whatever game it is less enjoyable for others. **Every single game**. Not just League. This is a battle that cannot be won on a large scale. Little bits and pieces here and there can be banned for whatever offence they have, but actually winning? Not going to happen.

The only ones who win are the ones who mute the others. They're the ones that are still able to enjoy their game. In the end, that's all that matters. If eventually, that person who was muted gets banned for bad behavior, so be it. It no longer matters to the person who muted them. They're muted and technically no longer exist.

Basically: people need to step up for themselves and learn how to mute people. Sitting on their hands, taking it and saying "why doesn't Riot do anything about this?!" is victimizing themselves. Putting all the weight on Riot and Lyte to solve every single issue in their game when they give you the tools to ignore and/or block people that are toxic is just straight up wrong, not to mention *impossible*.

Muting people might not solve the problem at its source, but its source is impossible, **literally impossible** to get to, because it isn't **just** in LoL, it's everywhere. That's reality, and good luck changing reality.

>The only ones who win are the ones who mute the others.

Cite your source, please.
>Basically: people need to step up for themselves and learn how to mute people.

Lyte basically said this argument is weak. If you have to mute someone, the damage is done. They've already done something to you to make you mute them. The mute button stops the bleeding, but it doesn't close the wound. Your game experience is already worse, the mute button stops it from being much worse. A mute button is not a strong argument for limiting toxicity because of this.
Unless you go into a game and immediately mute everyone before they say anything. But then you risk muting teammates use the chat for it's intended use like asking to group or suggesting a lane swap or asking the support to play more aggressive or calling for jungler help.
>Putting all the weight on Riot and Lyte to solve every single issue in their game when they give you the tools to ignore and/or block people that are toxic is just straight up wrong

Just the same, the mute button's existence doesn't give people free reign to be a dick. Toxicity will forever exist, but that doesn't mean Riot should accept that and  stop making decisions that can reduce that potential toxicity. Not allowing voicechat is one such step. Being able to verbally chat with your teammates is a huge boon, but it has so much potential for nastiness that it's not worth the risks.
>Muting people might not solve the problem at its source, but its source is impossible, literally impossible to get to, because it isn't just in LoL, it's everywhere. That's reality, and good luck changing reality.

It's that kind of defeatist attitude that Riot is trying to stop from festering in it's playerbase. Toxicity should never be seen as "just a part of the game", but rather "something I can help Riot to get rid of".

Voice chat still sounds like aids.

I've played a lot of FPS games with voice chat (Both on console and PC) and on nearly every one of them, I insta mute all the players whenever I get in a game. 

With the kind of community that league has (Very similar to these FPS's, if not a bit worse) I would expect nothing different.

I generally opt out if voice chat is available.  A big reason is that I often play at night and talking wakes people up who then interrupt me.  Annoying if I'm just playing an FPS, but I'm not going to risk the leave in LoL
